Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2009 05:53PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Virginia, Thank you so much for the detail that you have provided.  It really makes me believe that I can do this too!  The fact that you are working and attending business meetings is amazing.  I told my boss that I'm not sure if I will be able to work while going through chemo.  I guess, I'll just have to wait and see.  I will do some more research on the cold cap.  I'll be anxious to see how your hair does as time goes on.  You go girl!  You are amazing. Lisa

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 07:38PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Hi, my name is Lisa.  I was diagnosed with IDC on July 22nd.  I will be going in for surgery tomorrow.  I have my medical oncology consult on September 9th and I assume that I will be starting chemo before the end of the month of September is over.  Since I have not met with the medical oncologist yet, I do not know what type of chemo regimen that I will be on.  I've been told that it will depend on the final pathology results from surgery.  This forum has taught me so much about chemo and I am inspired by all of the strong woman that are facing this disease.  We can do this!!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 07:46PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Carcharm, You are not a loonatic.  Your feelings are normal.  When I was diagnosed with cancer, I couldn't eat or sleep.  I had panic attacks and I felt like I was going to pass out.  My nerves were rocked to their core.  What helped me was learning about what I was about to face.  Knowledge is power.  There are many posts on this forum that can help you.  And, we are here for you.  I haven't started my chemo yet but I'm sure that I will feel the same way.  It's natural to fear the unknown.  It's awesome that your son is there to help.  Prayers and hugs coming your way!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 03:34PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Well ladies, I got some news at my re-excision yesterday.  My doctor told me that I was moved back to stage 2a.  Apparently, I had two tumors removed last week and pathology only listed one of them on the path report - the larger of the two, which was 1.3 CM.  My sugeon and I both thought that it was strange that imaging has always shown a 3.6 ish CM tumor.  So, after she went back and checked into, she found out that they only listed one tumor.  She then found out that the two tumors 1.3 cm and < 1 cm were joined by a "thread" of some sort.  So, now they are looking at the two as one and I am back to stage 2a.  Honestly....................this stuff is so hard to understand sometimes.  Anyway, I meet with my Oncologist next week to talk about when chemo will start.  Welcome Shawna, sorry that I can't be of help yet but you've come to the right place.  We have ladies that have gone through treatments at the end of Aug that can help you.  Jeanne, I pray that everything went well for you yesterday.  Let us know we are all thinking of you.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 02:01PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Hi to all of the new ladies!  I know that you'll be well taken care of on this thread!  I am going to the oncologist tomorrow to find out what regimen that I will be on and and when I will begin treatment.  Although I have gone through numeous tests, scans and procedures, and have had surgery (twice due to a required re-excision), the reality of having cancer is still so unbelievable.  I do think that chemo will make me feel more like a cancer patient.  Although I do not want to define myself as such, I am worried about the mental part of getting through the next few months. I am quite nervous to meet with the onco tomorrow even though I want to get going with my treatment.  It's a love/hate thing, I guess.  I love that we have drugs to kill off cancer cells but I hate the thought of losing my hair, feeling sick, and etc.  As with all of things that I've had to do since finding out about the cancer, I will move forward and GET ER DONE! Hugs to all - Lisa
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 06:22PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Hi ladies, I met with my onco today and asked him about the cold caps.  He laughed and said "those don't work".  He then proceeded to say, "If you hair doesn't fall out, then I am not doing my job properly.'  When I told him that I heard of other woman having success with the caps, he quickly dismissed the topic.  Uuuhhggg Lisa
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 10:58PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Hi Ladies, I'm checking in.  Had my surgery on 8/26/09 as planned.   Met with my surgeon yesterday to go over pathology report.  I found out that my cancer was only 1.3 cm and not 3.8 cm as they had measured in MRI, Ultrasound, and Mammogram.  Also, they confirmed that lymph nodes were clear.  The doc said that this moves me from stage 2a to stage 1.  I'm meeting with the medical oncologist on 9/9/09 to discuss chemotherapy.  I'm getting really nervous.  Thank you sisters who have already started chemo and are keeping us informed.  You are all so brave.  I hope that I can buck it up as they say, when my day comes.  London-Virginia, how did you become aware of the cold cap.  My medical center hasn't even mentioned it as an option.  I don't think that it is common here in the Midwestern part of the US.  I would love to give it a try.  Do you need more than one?  Do you keep it in the freezer?   Christine1000, it sucks that you have to go through this again.  I'm glad that you found us.    KRCLL, my heart goes out to you.  I hope that your surgery went well.  My thoughts are with you. Lisa

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 06:30PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: Hi ladies and welcome to all new ladies, I haven't started chemo yet.  I am waiting for the results of my Oncotype DX test.  My Onco indicated that due to my age (40) that I should get chemo unless my score comes back in the low range.  My regimen will be 4XTC and I will begin the last week of September.  I will not get a port. I have been looking at wigs online but have not yet walked into a wig store, nor have I ever tried a wig on.  So, I have a couple of dumb wig questions for anyone who would care to respond: 1.  Has anyone ordered a wig online? 2.  How are the wigs secured so that they do not slip or fall off? 3.  Are they scratchy? I've found some cute hats on headcovers.com.  I haven't ordered any yet but they seem to be a little more up to date than other sites that I have seen. Thanks - Lisa

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 08:38PM BoyMom_2009 wrote: I had the same surgery on August 26th and I agree that the incision from the sentinel node hurts more than the lumpectomy.  I haven't noticed sharp pain like you mention but I have had that pins and needles feeling in my arm.  I had the sentinel node and one additional node removed.  It sounds like this will be something that we deal with for a long time.  I'm going for my surgical check up today and plan to ask about this very thing.  Lisa
